content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Ashley Mitchell: I was born and raised in the United States, specifically in the East North Central region, and I've always felt a strong connection to my roots. Growing up in a family where my father had a graduate degree and my mother worked full-time, I was exposed to both education and the value of hard work from an early age. We lived in a comfortable home, and while my family wasn't extremely wealthy, we were definitely far above average in terms of income. I remember my parents always emphasizing the importance of faith, and we were devout Catholics, attending church every Sunday and participating in religious activities throughout the year. I moved to Chicago when I was 16, which was a big change for me, but I was able to stay in the same state, which made the transition a bit easier. I went on to earn my bachelor's degree, and I'm currently working full-time in a stable job that I enjoy. I've never been married, and I don't see myself getting married anytime soon. I speak a bit of Spanish from growing up in a community with a lot of bilingual families, and I'm proud of my Scottish heritage, even though I've never been to Scotland myself. Life has been pretty straightforward for me, but I've always tried to stay true to my values and work hard to build a good future.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Ashley Mitchell: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads moment for me. It happened right after I graduated from college. I had two job offers: one was a stable position in a corporate setting in Chicago, and the other was an opportunity to work in a smaller town in the same state, but with a nonprofit organization focused on community development. I was torn because the corporate job offered a clear path for advancement and a higher salary, which aligned with my family's emphasis on financial stability. But the nonprofit job felt more in line with my values—helping others, making a difference, and staying connected to my community. I remember talking it over with my parents, and while they encouraged me to take the corporate job for security, I felt a deep sense of purpose with the nonprofit. I chose the nonprofit path, and while it hasn't been as financially lucrative, I've grown so much personally and have been able to give back in ways that matter to me. That decision really shaped who I am today—more compassionate, more grounded, and more committed to living by my values even when it's not the easiest choice.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Ashley Mitchell: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I spent a lot of time reflecting on what I truly wanted out of life, and I realized that money and status weren't the only things that mattered. I wanted to feel like my work had meaning, and I wanted to be part of something bigger than myself. I remember sitting in my apartment in Chicago, staring out the window, and just knowing that if I took the corporate job, I might look back one day and wonder if I had missed my purpose. I didn't want to live a life of 'what ifs.' So I made the decision with my heart, even though it meant taking a step back in terms of financial security. I believe that when you make choices based on your values, even if they're harder, they end up being the ones that define you the most.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Ashley Mitchell: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during that time would have made a difference. My mother, in particular, was someone I leaned on. She had her own experiences growing up in a working-class family and had always emphasized the importance of doing what felt right, even if it wasn't the easiest path. I remember one evening, after I had been struggling with the decision for weeks, she sat down with me and shared a story about her own life—how she had turned down a job that would have given her financial security in favor of pursuing something that made her happy. Her words really resonated with me. I also reached out to a mentor I had from college, someone who had worked in the nonprofit sector. He gave me some practical advice about what to expect and helped me see that the nonprofit path wasn't as unstable as I feared. In the end, I think having those people in my life helped me make a decision that was both thoughtful and true to who I am.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Ashley Mitchell: I currently don't have a partner or children, and I don't see myself pursuing marriage or having children in the near future. My focus has been on building a stable career and giving back to my community through my work with the nonprofit. My family is still very important to me, though. My parents live in the same state, and we stay in touch regularly. My father is a professor at a local university, and my mother works part-time in administrative support, but she's always been a strong influence in my life. I also have a younger sister who's in college, and we're very close. While I've never been one for big family gatherings, I do value the support and love my family has always given me. I think it's important to have a strong foundation of family, even if your life takes you in different directions. I'm grateful for the family I have and the values they've instilled in me.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my values have shaped the path I've taken in life. From my childhood, where I was raised with a strong emphasis on faith, education, and hard work, to the pivotal decision I made after college to choose a nonprofit career over a more financially secure corporate path, I've always tried to stay true to who I am. It wasn't an easy choice, but knowing that I made it with my heart and not just my head has given me a deep sense of fulfillment. I'm grateful for the support of my family, especially my mother and my mentor, who helped me see that living by my values is more important than following the easiest route. Even now, as I continue to build my career and maintain close ties with my family, I feel grounded in the choices I've made. Reflecting on these topics has reinforced how much my past has influenced my present, and I'm proud of the person I've become.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Ashley Mitchell: My immediate family consists of my parents, my younger sister, and my grandmother, who lives with us in Chicago. My grandmother is a big part of our family dynamic—she's in her late 70s now, but she's still very spry and has a sharp wit that keeps us all laughing. She moved in with us a few years ago after my grandfather passed away, and while it was a difficult transition for everyone, I'm grateful we made the choice to care for her. She's been a source of wisdom and comfort for me, especially during tough times. I remember growing up, she would tell me stories about her own youth in Scotland, even though she never actually visited the country herself. Those stories sparked my curiosity about my heritage, and I've always felt a connection to my Scottish roots through her. I think it's important to keep family close, especially as we get older, and I'm lucky to have a strong, supportive family that's always there for me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Ashley Mitchell: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends who have been with me through a lot of life's ups and downs. One of them, Sarah, I met in college—we were in the same nonprofit club, and we've been best friends ever since. She's the one who encouraged me to take the nonprofit job after graduation, and she's been my biggest supporter ever since. We don't see each other as often as I'd like because she moved to another state for work, but we stay in touch through regular calls and messages. There's also my mentor, Mark, who I mentioned earlier. He's more of a father figure to me in many ways. He's been guiding me through my career and has always been there with advice, whether I needed it or not. I also have a small group of friends from my church community—some of them are coworkers, others are just people I've connected with through shared faith. They've been a great source of support and encouragement, especially in moments when I've felt uncertain about my path. I think it's important to have people in your life who challenge you, support you, and remind you of your purpose. I'm grateful for all of them, even if we don't always have time to spend together.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Ashley Mitchell: I live in a neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago, specifically in the area around 1500 W Monroe St. It's a diverse part of the city, with a mix of old and new buildings, and a lot of community spirit. There are some historic apartments, a few small businesses, and a couple of community centers that host events throughout the year. I really appreciate the sense of community here—there are always people coming together for local initiatives, whether it's a food drive, a neighborhood clean-up, or a cultural festival. My apartment is in a building that's been around for a while, but it's well-maintained, and the management is pretty responsive. I live on the third floor, and I have a small balcony where I like to sit and read or just enjoy the city views. The area isn't perfect—there are definitely some challenges, like the occasional noise from the street or the need for more investment in certain parts of the neighborhood—but I feel like I'm part of something that's growing and evolving. It's a place where I can be both grounded and inspired, and I think that's why I've chosen to stay here even as my career has developed.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Ashley Mitchell: I feel pretty safe in my neighborhood, though I wouldn't say it's without its challenges. There are definitely areas where I'm more cautious, especially at night or when I'm out alone, but overall, I've never felt threatened. The sense of community here is pretty strong, and I've gotten to know a lot of my neighbors over the years. We look out for each other, and there's a mutual respect that I think helps keep things from getting too chaotic. I also try to be mindful of my surroundings, like keeping my doors locked and being aware of who's around me. I think safety is something you have to be proactive about, and I've learned to balance that with the positive aspects of living in a vibrant, diverse area. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I feel like I can navigate it with confidence.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Ashley Mitchell: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, I love the energy of the city and the sense of community that makes this neighborhood feel like home. I've met so many interesting people, from my neighbors to the folks I work with at the nonprofit. We often collaborate on local projects, and it's incredibly fulfilling to see the impact we can have together. On the other hand, there are definitely days when the noise, the traffic, or the occasional tension in the area can feel overwhelming. I've had to learn how to set boundaries for myself—like making sure I have quiet evenings at home or taking time to recharge when needed. I also appreciate the diversity of the area; there are so many cultures represented here, and it's always interesting to learn from others. I think the key to making this place work for me has been finding balance—being engaged with the community while also knowing when to step back and take care of myself. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade this neighborhood for anything. It's where I've grown, where I've found my purpose, and where I feel most connected to the life I've chosen.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. It's easy to get caught up in the day-to-day, but when I take a step back, I realize how much my family—especially my parents, sister, and grandmother—has been a constant source of love and support. They've always encouraged me to stay true to myself, even when the path wasn't the easiest. Living in my neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago has also been a big part of who I am. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I've found a sense of purpose here through my work and the community around me. I feel safe, even if I have to be mindful of my surroundings, and I appreciate the diversity and energy that makes this place unique. Overall, these questions reminded me of how much my relationships and environment have influenced my journey, and I'm grateful for the life I've built so far.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Ashley Mitchell: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but there's also a lot of variety depending on what's going on at the nonprofit. Mondays are usually my busiest day because that's when we have our team meetings and plan out the week's initiatives. I often start the day early, around 7 a.m., with a quick breakfast and a walk around the neighborhood to get my thoughts in order. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about execution—whether it's organizing a community event, meeting with local partners, or helping out with outreach programs. I love the hands-on work, even if it can be exhausting at times. Thursdays are a bit more flexible; I might spend the morning in meetings or on administrative tasks, and then in the afternoon, I like to take a break and catch up with friends or attend a church event. Fridays are usually lighter, but I still have a lot to wrap up before the weekend. On weekends, I try to relax as much as possible—sometimes I'll meet up with Sarah for coffee or a walk, or I'll spend time with my family. I also enjoy reading or doing some light exercise, like yoga or a jog around the neighborhood. It's not always perfect, but I find that this rhythm helps me stay grounded and focused on what matters most to me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Ashley Mitchell: I work full-time at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' which focuses on youth education and neighborhood development. I'm part of the outreach and program coordination team, which means I spend a lot of my time organizing workshops, connecting with local schools, and collaborating with other community groups. My work hours are typically from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, though I often stay late a few days a week when we're preparing for events or meetings. I love the variety of the job—it's never the same day twice. Some days I'm in a classroom helping kids with homework, and other days I'm meeting with city officials to discuss funding opportunities. It can be exhausting, but I find it incredibly rewarding. I think the best part is seeing the impact we make, even in small ways. Whether it's a child who's gained confidence through our programs or a neighbor who's become more involved in their community, those moments remind me why I chose this path. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Ashley Mitchell: Outside of work, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I try to wake up early most mornings, even on weekends, because I find that starting the day with a bit of quiet time helps me feel more centered. I usually do a short meditation or read a chapter from a book—something that helps me disconnect from the noise of the city and reconnect with myself. I also make it a point to cook at home as much as possible, even if it's just a simple meal. I've always believed in the value of good food, and I think it's one of the few things I can control in a world that can feel pretty unpredictable. On the weekends, I sometimes volunteer at a local food pantry or help out with a neighborhood clean-up project. It's not always about grand gestures—it's the small, consistent actions that keep me grounded. I also try to stay active, whether it's going for a run, taking a yoga class, or just walking around the neighborhood. I think physical activity helps me process my thoughts and stay focused on what's important. Overall, I've learned that having these little routines helps me maintain a sense of stability, especially in a city as fast-paced as Chicago.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Ashley Mitchell: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more time for self-reflection and journaling. I started doing this a few months ago after realizing how much I was relying on others for emotional support and guidance. I wanted to find a way to connect more deeply with myself and process the challenges I face in my work and personal life. Now, I set aside about 15 minutes each morning before I start my day to write down my thoughts, intentions, and any gratitude I feel. It's been a small but meaningful shift—it helps me stay grounded and reminds me of why I'm doing the work I'm doing. I also began setting aside an hour each week to review my progress, both professionally and personally. It's not always easy to look at myself objectively, but I find that it helps me stay focused on my goals and values. I think this change has made me more intentional with my time and more aware of the little things that bring me joy, like the sound of rain against the windows or the smell of fresh coffee in the morning.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Ashley Mitchell: I don't have children of my own yet, and I don't see myself having them in the near future. My focus has been on building a stable career and giving back to my community through my work with the nonprofit. That said, I have a younger sister who's in college, and I often think about what her life might look like during the school year. For her, a typical weekday would start early—she usually gets up around 7 a.m., has a quick breakfast, and then heads to class. She's majoring in social work, so her schedule is pretty full with classes, internships, and study groups. After school, she often participates in volunteer opportunities or meets up with friends for coffee or a walk. I admire her dedication and the way she balances her responsibilities with her personal life. While I haven't had the experience of raising children myself, I've watched my sister grow into a compassionate and driven young woman, and I know that if I ever do have children, I'd want to raise them with the same values that were instilled in me—faith, education, and a strong sense of community.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines has made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. My family—especially my parents, sister, and grandmother—has always been a constant source of love and support, and I'm grateful for the values they've instilled in me. Living in my neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago has also been a big part of who I am. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I've found a sense of purpose here through my work and the community around me. I feel safe, even if I have to be mindful of my surroundings, and I appreciate the diversity and energy that makes this place unique. My daily routines, from work to personal habits like meditation and journaling, help me stay grounded and focused on what matters most to me. Overall, these questions reminded me of how much my relationships and environment have influenced my journey, and I'm grateful for the life I've built so far.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Ashley Mitchell: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty fortunate. I try to take care of myself through regular exercise, a balanced diet, and mindfulness practices like meditation and journaling. I work out a few times a week, usually doing yoga or going for a run in the park near my apartment. I also make an effort to eat healthy meals most of the time—though I'll admit I do have my occasional pizza nights. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid, and I think that's helped me stay in good shape. I don't have any major health issues, but I do keep up with regular check-ups and screenings. I also try to manage stress through my routines, which I think is just as important as physical health. I've learned that taking care of your body and mind goes hand in hand, and I'm grateful that I've been able to maintain a healthy lifestyle so far. It's not always perfect, but I believe that small, consistent habits make a big difference in the long run.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Ashley Mitchell: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, I live in a city where there are so many options for fresh food, parks, and fitness classes. I love that I can walk or bike to most places, and I enjoy the variety of healthy eating choices, whether it's a smoothie at the local café or a farmer's market nearby. My routines, like morning meditation and regular exercise, also help me stay on track. But there are definitely challenges too. The fast-paced lifestyle of Chicago can make it tempting to skip a workout or grab a quick, less healthy meal when I'm busy. I also struggle with consistency, especially when I'm overwhelmed with work or personal responsibilities. There are days when I feel like I'm not doing enough, and that can lead to burnout. What helps me push through is reminding myself that health isn't about perfection—it's about showing up, even on the tough days, and making small choices that add up over time. I think the key is balance, and I'm learning to be kinder to myself when I slip up, rather than getting discouraged.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Ashley Mitchell: In the past two years, I've been pretty healthy overall, but there was one incident that stands out. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent lower back pain, which I initially dismissed as just stress or poor posture from sitting at my desk for long hours. But after a few months of it getting worse, I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist. It turned out that I had developed a minor herniated disc, likely from a combination of my work habits and some old injuries from when I was in college. The physical therapy was tough at first—it required me to do a lot of stretching and strengthening exercises that I wasn't used to—but over time, it got better. I also had to make some changes to my workspace, like adjusting my chair and taking more frequent breaks to stand and move around. It was a humbling experience, but it reminded me how important it is to listen to my body and take care of myself, even when life gets busy. Now, I'm much more mindful of my posture and have incorporated more movement into my daily routine, which has made a real difference in how I feel overall.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Ashley Mitchell: While the back pain did make some days more challenging, especially when I had long meetings or was on my feet for extended periods, it never really got to the point where it affected my ability to work or care for others. I had to learn how to pace myself and take breaks when needed, which actually helped me become more efficient in my job. I also made sure to communicate with my team when I needed to adjust my schedule or take a few extra minutes to stretch. It wasn't easy at first, but over time, I found a rhythm that allowed me to manage both my health and my responsibilities. I think the experience taught me the importance of self-compassion and the value of small, consistent changes. I'm grateful that I was able to address the issue before it became something more serious, and now I'm more aware of how my body is telling me when it needs rest or care.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Ashley Mitchell: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of growth and reflection. There have been moments of deep fulfillment, especially when I see the impact of our work at the nonprofit—whether it's a student who's found confidence through our mentorship programs or a neighbor who's become more involved in community initiatives. Those moments remind me why I chose this path, and they keep me motivated even on the hardest days. At the same time, there have been times when I've felt the weight of responsibility, especially with the demands of my job and the ongoing challenges in the neighborhood. I've had to learn how to lean into my support system more—whether it's my family, my friends, or my faith. I've also been working on setting clearer boundaries for myself, which has helped me maintain a better balance between work and personal life. Overall, I feel more grounded than ever, and I'm grateful for the journey I've been on. It's not always easy, but I believe it's all part of becoming the person I want to be.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes in routine, health, and daily habits has made me reflect on how much I've grown in the past year. Incorporating journaling and self-reflection into my mornings has helped me stay more intentional with my time and reminded me of the values that guide me. At the same time, I've come to appreciate the importance of taking care of my physical and mental health, especially after dealing with the lower back pain. It's been a humbling experience, but it's also taught me that health isn't about perfection—it's about showing up for myself, even on the tough days. I've learned to be kinder to myself when I slip up and to celebrate the small, consistent choices that add up over time. These changes have helped me feel more grounded and in control of my life, and I'm grateful for the lessons they've brought.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Ashley Mitchell: I think I've been fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I've definitely had moments where I felt overwhelmed or uncertain about my path. There were times, especially during the early days of my nonprofit work, when the weight of responsibility felt heavy—like I was trying to do too much with too little. I remember one particular period where I was juggling multiple projects, and I started feeling like I wasn't making enough of a difference. It was during that time that I realized I needed to take a step back and reconnect with the reasons I had chosen this work in the first place. I started leaning more on my faith, my family, and the small but meaningful routines I had developed, like journaling and meditation. Those practices helped me regain my sense of purpose and reminded me that it's okay to feel vulnerable sometimes. I think the key for me has been learning to ask for help when I need it and to be gentle with myself when things don't go as planned. I'm not immune to stress or doubt, but I've learned that they don't have to define me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Ashley Mitchell: For my family, the past year has been a mix of support, growth, and moments of reflection. My parents have been incredibly proud of the work I'm doing with the nonprofit, even though they've always been more traditional in their views. They've never been ones to question my choices, but I can tell they've had their own moments of worry, especially when I was juggling so much at once. My mother, in particular, has been my biggest cheerleader—she always reminds me that I'm doing something meaningful, even when it's hard. My father, on the other hand, has been more focused on the practical side, but he's started to see the value in what I'm doing, especially after I shared some stories about the kids we've helped. My sister has been going through her own challenges with school and work, and I've been there for her as much as I can, even when I'm busy. It's been a year of learning how to balance my own responsibilities with being there for the people I love. I think, in many ways, we've all grown closer through it, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Ashley Mitchell: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life. Being raised Catholic, I grew up with a deep sense of faith that shaped not only my values but also how I approach challenges and relationships. My family attended church every Sunday, and we participated in religious activities throughout the year, like Lenten services or community outreach events. Even now, my faith continues to be a source of strength and guidance. I find comfort in prayer, especially during difficult times, and I believe that living with integrity and compassion is a reflection of my beliefs. I also appreciate the sense of community that comes with being part of a faith group—whether it's through my church or the nonprofit work I do, I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself. That said, I don't see my faith as something rigid or unchanging. I've always believed that spirituality is a personal journey, and I'm open to learning and growing in my understanding of it. What matters most to me is living in a way that honors the values I was taught—faith, family, and service to others.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Ashley Mitchell: I do use social media, though not as much as some of my friends. I have a Facebook account where I stay in touch with family and old friends, especially my sister and my parents. I also follow a few pages related to my work with the nonprofit, like community development initiatives or local education programs. It's a way for me to stay informed and connected to the causes I care about. I don't use Instagram or Twitter as much, mostly because I find them to be more about quick updates or news, which doesn't really align with how I like to engage with the world. That said, I do occasionally use Instagram to follow some local artists or community leaders who share inspiring stories about Chicago. I think social media can be a powerful tool for good when used intentionally, and I try to use it in a way that supports my values and keeps me grounded in the community I care about.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Ashley Mitchell: Honestly, I haven't relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, my support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and my faith community. That said, I do think social media can be a double-edged sword. On one hand, it can connect you with people who share your values or are going through similar experiences, which can be comforting. On the other hand, it can also be overwhelming or even discouraging if you're not careful about what you consume. I've seen posts from friends who are going through hard times, and while it's good to know they're not alone, I also try to remember that online support isn't a substitute for real, face-to-face connection. For me, the real support has always been in person, whether it's a phone call from my mother, a conversation with Sarah, or a prayer with my church community. I think it's important to use these platforms mindfully and not let them replace the relationships that truly matter.

Going through the questions about my health and recent experiences has made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past year. It's been a journey of learning to listen to my body, setting boundaries, and finding balance between work, personal life, and self-care. The lower back pain was a wake-up call that reminded me how important it is to take care of myself, not just in the physical sense, but also emotionally and mentally. I've come to realize that health isn't about perfection—it's about showing up for myself, even on the tough days, and making small, consistent choices that add up over time. I'm grateful for the support of my family and friends, who have been there for me when I needed them most. It's also been a reminder of how much I value my faith and the sense of purpose it brings to my life. I've learned to be kinder to myself when I slip up and to celebrate the progress I've made, no matter how small. These experiences have helped me feel more grounded and in control of my life, and I'm grateful for the lessons they've brought.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Ashley Mitchell: In the past year, I've noticed a shift in my emotional landscape—there's been more awareness of my own stress and how it shows up in my body and mind. I used to push through without really stopping to check in with myself, but now I make a conscious effort to pause and reflect. I've started incorporating more mindfulness into my daily routine, like taking a few deep breaths before starting my workday or setting aside time to journal about my feelings. I've also leaned more heavily on my faith, especially during moments when I feel overwhelmed. Prayer and attending church have become anchors for me, helping me find clarity and peace. I've learned that it's okay to feel stressed or worried, but what matters is how I respond to those feelings. I've started setting clearer boundaries between work and personal time, which has helped me feel more in control. I'm still learning, and there are definitely days when I feel like I'm not doing enough, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and celebrate the small progress I make. Overall, I feel more equipped to handle life's challenges, and I'm grateful for the tools I've developed to cope with stress and stay emotionally grounded.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Ashley Mitchell: In terms of making ends meet, I've always been pretty mindful of my budget, especially since I chose a nonprofit career over a higher-paying corporate job. My biggest expenses last month were rent, which is a significant chunk of my income since I live in a well-maintained apartment on the West Side of Chicago. After that, groceries and utilities come next—especially with the cost of living here, I try to be careful about meal planning and using energy efficiently. I also have a car payment, which is something I don't take for granted, and I make sure to keep it well-maintained. Transportation costs can add up, especially with the way I travel for work events or community outreach. I also set aside money for personal expenses like books, meditation classes, and occasional outings with friends or family. While I don't have a lot of discretionary income, I've learned to prioritize what matters most—whether it's supporting my community, staying healthy, or maintaining my relationships. I also try to save a little each month, even if it's just a small amount, because I believe in being prepared for the future. It's not always easy, but I've come to accept that my financial situation is what it is, and I focus on what I can control rather than what I can't.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Ashley Mitchell: My household spending last month was around $2,800, which is pretty typical for me. I usually spend about the same each month, give or take a few hundred dollars depending on any unexpected expenses or events. The majority of that goes to rent, which is around $1,200, and utilities, which are about $200. Groceries are another big chunk—roughly $400 a month, which I try to keep in check by meal prepping and buying in bulk when possible. My car payment is around $300, and I also set aside about $150 for transportation costs like gas and public transit. I spend about $100 on personal items, like books, meditation classes, or a small treat for myself, and another $100 on miscellaneous things like phone bills, internet, and occasional outings with friends or family. I also try to save around $100 each month, even if it's just a little, because I believe in being prepared for the future. It's not a lot, but it's enough to live comfortably and stay focused on what matters most to me.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Ashley Mitchell: We rent our home. I live in a three-bedroom apartment on the West Side of Chicago, which I share with my grandmother. Renting has always been the norm for me, especially since I chose a career path that prioritizes purpose over higher earnings. I've never owned a home, and honestly, I don't see myself buying one anytime soon. Renting gives me more flexibility, especially with my work schedule and the possibility of needing to move for new opportunities in the nonprofit sector. Plus, it's easier to manage with my current income, and I can focus my resources on things that matter more to me, like supporting my community and maintaining a stable lifestyle for myself and my grandmother.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Ashley Mitchell: Over the past year, my bills have had some fluctuations, especially with the seasons and holidays. For example, during the winter months, my utility bills—particularly heating—went up a bit, which was something I had to budget for. I also noticed an increase in grocery costs around the holidays, especially when I was hosting small gatherings with friends or family. There were a few months where I had to pay for unexpected repairs, like a leak in the apartment that required a plumber's visit. On the other hand, some expenses stayed pretty consistent, like my rent and car payment. I also found that my transportation costs varied depending on how much I was traveling for work events or community outreach. I've learned to set aside a little extra each month for these kinds of surprises, which has helped me stay more prepared. Overall, while there have been some ups and downs, I've managed to keep my spending pretty stable by tracking my expenses and adjusting as needed.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 has made me reflect on how much my family and faith have been pillars in my life, especially during the past year. My family has always been a source of support, even when I've been juggling a busy work schedule and personal challenges. Their love and encouragement have reminded me of why I chose the path I'm on, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. At the same time, my faith continues to be a guiding force, offering me comfort and strength when things feel overwhelming. I've come to realize that while social media can be a tool for connection, it's not a substitute for the real, meaningful relationships I have with the people I care about most. These reflections have reinforced how important it is to stay grounded in the values and relationships that truly matter, even in a fast-paced and often uncertain world.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Ashley Mitchell: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. I've always believed that saving is about preparation rather than luxury, and it's something I started doing early on, even when I was in college. Right now, I set aside around $100 a month, which might not seem like much, but over time, it adds up. I keep that money in a separate account that's not easily accessible, which helps me avoid the temptation to spend it on things I don't really need. I also have a small emergency fund that I've been building over the years, mostly from unexpected windfalls or bonuses from work. It's not a huge amount, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I have something to fall back on if needed. I think saving is about discipline and intention, and I've learned that even small, consistent actions can make a real difference in the long run.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Ashley Mitchell: For me, saving has always been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. I know that buying a house isn't really in my immediate future, especially with the way my career is structured. Instead, I focus on building a small emergency fund that can cover a few months of essential expenses if something were to happen. Over the past year, I've been more intentional about this, especially after dealing with my back pain and realizing how important it is to have a financial cushion for unexpected medical costs or other surprises. I also save a little bit each month for personal growth—like funding a course or attending a workshop that could help me advance in my work or deepen my understanding of community development. It's not about big goals, but about small, consistent steps that give me a sense of security and control over my future.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Ashley Mitchell: My occupation is as a Program Coordinator at a nonprofit organization called 'Community Roots,' where I focus on youth education and neighborhood development. In this role, my work involves organizing workshops, connecting with local schools, and collaborating with other community groups to create programs that support at-risk youth and promote educational opportunities. One of the most important activities I do is designing and leading after-school mentorship programs that help students with homework, life skills, and career guidance. I also spend a lot of time meeting with local leaders, city officials, and potential donors to secure funding and support for our initiatives. The most rewarding part of my job is seeing the impact we make—whether it's a student who gains confidence through our programs or a neighbor who becomes more involved in their community. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel overwhelmed by the scale of the challenges we face, but I'm reminded every day why I chose this path. I believe in the power of education and community, and I'm committed to doing the work that makes a real difference, even if it's not always recognized or rewarded in the traditional sense.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Ashley Mitchell: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year and the number of projects we're juggling. Mondays are typically the busiest, as we have team meetings and plan out the week's initiatives, and Fridays often involve wrapping up loose ends or preparing for the next week. There are also times when I have to stay late a few nights a week, especially when we're launching new programs or organizing community events. I've learned to be flexible with my schedule, and while it can be demanding, I find that the work I do is deeply meaningful. I also make it a point to take breaks when needed, whether it's stepping outside for a few minutes or taking a short walk during lunch. It's important to me to maintain a balance between my professional responsibilities and my personal well-being, even if it doesn't always feel perfectly balanced.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Ashley Mitchell: No, I haven't had more than one job or business. I've always focused on one primary role at a time, especially since I chose a career path that requires a lot of dedication and emotional investment. While I've considered taking on part-time work or freelance projects in the past, I've found that spreading myself too thin can take away from the quality of the work I do in my nonprofit role. I believe in giving my full attention to the responsibilities I've committed to, and I've learned that trying to juggle multiple jobs often leads to burnout rather than fulfillment. That said, I've done some volunteer work on the side, especially during the holidays or community events, which I see as an extension of my values rather than a separate job. I think it's important to stay focused on what truly matters to you, and for me, that's been my work with the nonprofit and the people I serve.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 has made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding my own stress and emotional needs. I used to push through without really checking in with myself, but now I make a conscious effort to pause, breathe, and reflect each day. My faith has become even more important to me during these times, offering a sense of peace and clarity when things feel overwhelming. I've also learned the value of setting boundaries between work and personal life, which has helped me feel more in control and less drained. Financially, I've come to accept that my income isn't huge, but I've learned to live within my means and prioritize what truly matters—my community, my family, and my health. I'm grateful for the small but meaningful changes I've made, and I feel more grounded and equipped to handle life's challenges now than I ever have before.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Ashley Mitchell: In terms of my household income, we made approximately $2,500 last month. That's pretty consistent with what I usually earn, give or take a few hundred dollars depending on any extra hours I might have worked or grants we received through the nonprofit. My salary as a Program Coordinator at 'Community Roots' is around $32,000 a year, which covers my rent, utilities, groceries, and other essential expenses. I also receive a small stipend from the nonprofit for travel and event coordination, which helps with transportation and miscellaneous costs. While it's not a huge income, I've learned to live within my means and prioritize what truly matters—like supporting my community, staying healthy, and maintaining strong relationships with my family and friends. I don't have any other sources of income, but I'm grateful for the stability I have and the work I'm doing to make a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Ashley Mitchell: I've been at 'Community Roots' for about three years now, and it's been an incredible journey. The organization has a strong mission, and I feel fortunate to be part of a team that's genuinely committed to making a difference. In terms of benefits, we have health insurance coverage, which is something I really appreciate, especially after dealing with my back pain. We also get a certain number of paid days off each year—about 10 vacation days and 10 sick days, which gives me the flexibility to take time when I need it, whether it's for personal reasons or to recharge. The workplace culture is pretty collaborative, and while we don't have the same kind of perks as a corporate job, there's a real sense of purpose and community here. I also get a small stipend for travel and event coordination, which helps with some of the costs associated with my work. Overall, I don't make a lot of money, but I feel like I'm getting something much more valuable—meaningful work that aligns with my values and the opportunity to be part of something that truly matters.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Ashley Mitchell: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, who I'll call Lisa. She's been with the organization for a while and has a lot of experience in community development. She's supportive of my work and always encourages me to think creatively about how we can better serve the community. I admire her dedication and the way she leads with both compassion and strength. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of teamwork. We all share a common goal of making a difference, and that bond helps us get through the challenges we face. There are a few people I work closely with on a daily basis—like my colleague, James, who handles a lot of the administrative work for our programs. We've been through a lot together, from late nights preparing for events to the highs of seeing our programs make an impact. I think the key to our good relationships is that we all care deeply about what we do, and that shared purpose makes it easier to support each other, even when the work gets tough.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Ashley Mitchell: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility depending on what's going on with our programs. Most days, I start around 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5:00 p.m., but there are times when I need to stay late, especially if we're preparing for an event or meeting with a partner organization. On the flip side, there are days when I can leave a little early if things are wrapped up and there's no immediate need for me to stay. I also have the option to work from home a few days a week, which is a nice perk, especially when I need to focus on a project or take care of personal matters. That said, I do have to be flexible with my hours because the needs of the community come first. If a student needs extra support or a neighborhood initiative requires more attention, I'm willing to adjust my schedule to make sure we're there for them. It's not always the easiest balance, but I think the flexibility is worth it because it allows me to be present in the work I do and the people I serve.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Ashley Mitchell: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation, even if it's not what I would call abundant. I've made peace with the fact that my income isn't huge, and I've learned to live within my means while still prioritizing what truly matters—like supporting my community, staying healthy, and maintaining strong relationships with my family and friends. I know that money isn't everything, and I've been blessed with a stable job that allows me to do work I believe in. There are definitely days when I feel the weight of not having more financial security, especially when I see my peers in more lucrative careers, but I remind myself that I've chosen a path that aligns with my values, and I wouldn't trade that for anything. I also take comfort in the fact that I've built a small emergency fund and have a support system that helps me navigate life's unexpected challenges. While I'd love to have more financial freedom in the future, I'm grateful for what I have and the sense of purpose that comes with my work.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 has made me reflect on how my financial situation and work life are deeply intertwined with my values and priorities. It's interesting to think about how my bills fluctuate with the seasons and holidays, and how I've had to adapt my budget to accommodate those changes. While my income isn't huge, I've learned to live within my means and focus on what truly matters—supporting my community, staying healthy, and maintaining strong relationships with my family and friends. My work at the nonprofit is demanding, but it's also deeply fulfilling, and I feel a sense of purpose in what I do. I've come to accept that my financial situation is what it is, and I'm grateful for the stability I have. It's not about having more—it's about being content with what I have and using it to make a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Ashley Mitchell: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a professor at a local university, and he worked full-time throughout my childhood and into my teenage years. He was always very dedicated to his work, but he also made sure to be present for family events and to support my education. My mother worked part-time in administrative support for a few years while I was in high school, and she was always very hands-on with my sister and me. Even though she didn't have a full-time job, she was always involved in our lives, whether it was helping with homework, attending school events, or just being there for us when we needed her. I think their work ethic and the balance they found between career and family had a big influence on me. It showed me that it's possible to have a meaningful job while still being present for the people you love, and that's something I've tried to carry with me in my own life.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Ashley Mitchell: My father's job as a professor was both intellectually stimulating and deeply impactful. He taught courses in sociology, and his most important activities involved not only lecturing and grading papers but also mentoring students and conducting research on social inequality. He was always passionate about his work, and I remember him staying up late into the night writing articles or preparing for classes. What I admired most about him was how he balanced his demanding career with being a present father. He made time for family dinners, helped with homework, and even took us on weekend trips to museums or historical sites. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time in administrative support for a local nonprofit, which gave her a sense of purpose beyond just a paycheck. Her most important duties involved managing schedules, coordinating events, and ensuring that the organization ran smoothly. Even though her job wasn't as high-profile as my father's, she brought the same level of dedication and compassion to her work. She was always the one to remind me that every job, no matter how small, can make a difference in someone's life. Their work ethic and values have had a lasting influence on me, and I think that's why I chose a career in community development—because I want to make a meaningful impact, just like they did in their own ways.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Ashley Mitchell: My father worked at a local university, which was a public institution focused on providing higher education to students in our region. He was part of the sociology department, and his work involved teaching, research, and community engagement. He often brought his students into the neighborhood for field studies, which gave me a chance to see how academic work could directly impact people's lives. My mother worked for a small nonprofit organization that focused on supporting low-income families with administrative tasks like scheduling services, managing donations, and organizing community events. While her job wasn't as high-profile as my father's, she took pride in the work she did, and I remember her often saying that even small acts of service could make a big difference. Both of them made sacrifices to ensure that my sister and I had the opportunities they didn't, and I think that's why I've always believed in the value of education and community service. Their work wasn't just about earning a paycheck—it was about making a meaningful contribution, and that's something I carry with me in everything I do today.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Ashley Mitchell: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to continue growing in my work with the nonprofit, maybe even take on more leadership responsibilities or help expand our programs to reach more young people in the community. I also hope to maintain the balance I've worked so hard to build between my career, my health, and my relationships. I'd love to see more stability in my financial situation, not necessarily because I want more money for its own sake, but because it would give me more freedom to invest in opportunities that align with my values—like furthering my education or supporting local initiatives in new ways. I also hope to keep my family close, especially as my parents and grandmother get older. I want to be there for them, just as they've been there for me. And on a more personal level, I hope to continue growing in my faith and deepening my spiritual practice, because I believe that's where I find my greatest strength and sense of purpose. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to keep moving forward with intention, compassion, and a heart that's always open to learning and serving others.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Ashley Mitchell: What I value the most in my life is the combination of faith, family, and purpose. My faith gives me a sense of direction and peace, especially during difficult times. My family—my parents, my sister, and my grandmother—have always been my foundation, offering love, support, and guidance throughout my life. And purpose, whether it's through my work with the nonprofit, my relationships, or the small ways I try to make a difference in my neighborhood, is what keeps me grounded and motivated. I believe that living a life aligned with these values is what truly matters, even if it doesn't always look like the traditional path of success. I value being able to wake up each day knowing I'm doing something that matters, even if it's not always easy. I also value the little things—the quiet moments with my grandmother, the laughter with my friends, the sense of community in my neighborhood. These are the things that make life rich and meaningful to me.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how deeply my work and financial situation are connected to my values and priorities. It's interesting to think about how my income, though modest, allows me to live a life that aligns with what I truly care about—supporting my community, staying healthy, and maintaining strong relationships with my family and friends. My job at the nonprofit is demanding, but it's also deeply fulfilling, and I feel a sense of purpose in what I do. I've come to accept that my financial situation is what it is, and I'm grateful for the stability I have. It's not about having more—it's about being content with what I have and using it to make a difference in the lives of others.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective experience for me. It reminded me of how much my values—faith, family, and purpose—have shaped the path I've taken, from my childhood in the East North Central region to my decision to work in the nonprofit sector after college. I've always tried to stay true to who I am, even when it meant choosing a less financially secure path, and I believe that those choices have defined me in meaningful ways. I'm grateful for the support of my family, especially my mother and grandmother, who have always encouraged me to follow my heart. I've also come to appreciate the small, consistent habits that keep me grounded—like journaling, meditation, and staying connected with the people and community that matter most. This reflection has reinforced how much my past has influenced my present, and I'm proud of the person I've become. I may not have everything I want, but I have everything I need, and that is something to be grateful for.
